claim: The original US constitution was written on parchment.

supporting.text: The original US Constitution is preserved in the National Archives, and historical records confirm it was written on parchment.

attacks.text: The original US Constitution is preserved in the National Archives, and historical records confirm it was written on parchment.
Some historical documents from the same era were written on vellum, not parchment, and there is debate over the exact material used for the original Constitution.
The National Archives explicitly states that the original Constitution is written on parchment, and vellum was not commonly used for such documents in the US at that time.
The term 'parchment' is sometimes used loosely to refer to any animal-skin writing material, which could include vellum, creating ambiguity in historical records.
Expert analysis and scientific testing confirm that the original Constitution is specifically on parchment, not vellum, as the two materials have distinct properties.

supporting.text: Parchment was the standard material for important legal documents in the 18th century due to its durability and longevity.

attacks.text: Parchment was the standard material for important legal documents in the 18th century due to its durability and longevity.
Some important 18th-century documents were written on vellum, which is distinct from parchment.
Vellum is actually a type of parchment, specifically made from calfskin, so the distinction doesn't undermine the original argument.
The Declaration of Independence was written on paper, showing parchment wasn't universally used for all important documents.
The Declaration was a working document, while the Constitution was meant to be permanent, explaining the different material choices.
Modern analysis shows the Constitution's ink has degraded significantly, questioning parchment's supposed durability.
The degradation is primarily due to poor storage conditions in the 19th century, not inherent flaws in parchment.

supporting.text: The physical appearance of the original Constitution, including its texture and aging, matches the characteristics of parchment.

attacks.text: The physical appearance of the original Constitution, including its texture and aging, matches the characteristics of parchment.
The original Constitution could have been written on high-quality paper designed to mimic parchment, as was common for important documents in the 18th century.
Historical records from the National Archives confirm that the original Constitution was indeed written on parchment, not paper.
The aging process of parchment and high-quality paper can be very similar, making visual and tactile identification unreliable without scientific testing.
Scientific analysis, including microscopic examination and material testing, has confirmed that the original Constitution is on animal-skin parchment.

supporting.text: Historical accounts from the Constitutional Convention in 1787 mention the use of parchment for the final document.

attacks.text: Historical accounts from the Constitutional Convention in 1787 mention the use of parchment for the final document.
Some historians argue that early drafts of the Constitution may have been written on paper before being transcribed onto parchment.
The National Archives confirms that the original signed Constitution is on parchment, supporting the claim about the final document.
There is no surviving physical evidence from 1787 that definitively proves the material used during the Convention itself.
Multiple contemporary accounts and letters from delegates reference parchment, making it the most reliable historical evidence available.

supporting.text: The National Archives' official documentation describes the Constitution as being written on parchment, which aligns with historical practices of the time.

attacks.text: The National Archives' official documentation describes the Constitution as being written on parchment, which aligns with historical practices of the time.

The National Archives' documentation specifically refers to the final, signed version as being on parchment, which does not contradict the existence of paper drafts.
